text:
James, a servant of God and of the Lord Jesus Christ,
To the twelve tribes in the Dispersion:
Greetings.
speaker: Narrator

text: Count it all joy, my brothers, when you meet trials of various kinds,
speaker: Narrator

text: for you know that the testing of your faith produces steadfastness.
speaker: Narrator

text: And let steadfastness have its full effect, that you may be perfect and complete, lacking in nothing.
speaker: Narrator

text: If any of you lacks wisdom, let him ask God, who gives generously to all without reproach, and it will be given him.
speaker: Narrator

text: But let him ask in faith, with no doubting, for the one who doubts is like a wave of the sea that is driven and tossed by the wind.
speaker: Narrator

text: For that person must not suppose that he will receive anything from the Lord;
speaker: Narrator

text: he is a double-minded man, unstable in all his ways.
speaker: Narrator

text: Let the lowly brother boast in his exaltation,
speaker: Narrator

text: and the rich in his humiliation, because like a flower of the grass he will pass away.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the sun rises with its scorching heat and withers the grass; its flower falls, and its beauty perishes. So also will the rich man fade away in the midst of his pursuits.
speaker: Narrator

text: Blessed is the man who remains steadfast under trial, for when he has stood the test he will receive the crown of life, which God has promised to those who love him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Let no one say when he is tempted, “I am being tempted by God”, for God cannot be tempted with evil, and he himself tempts no one.
speaker: Narrator

text: But each person is tempted when he is lured and enticed by his own desire.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then desire when it has conceived gives birth to sin, and sin when it is fully grown brings forth death.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not be deceived, my beloved brothers.
speaker: Narrator

text: Every good gift and every perfect gift is from above, coming down from the Father of lights with whom there is no variation or shadow due to change.
speaker: Narrator

text: Of his own will he brought us forth by the word of truth, that we should be a kind of firstfruits of his creatures.
speaker: Narrator

text: Know this, my beloved brothers: let every person be quick to hear, slow to speak, slow to anger;
speaker: Narrator

text: for the anger of man does not produce the righteousness of God.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore put away all filthiness and rampant wickedness and receive with meekness the implanted word, which is able to save your souls.
speaker: Narrator

text: But be doers of the word, and not hearers only, deceiving yourselves.
speaker: Narrator

text: For if anyone is a hearer of the word and not a doer, he is like a man who looks intently at his natural face in a mirror.
speaker: Narrator

text: For he looks at himself and goes away and at once forgets what he was like.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the one who looks into the perfect law, the law of liberty, and perseveres, being no hearer who forgets but a doer who acts, he will be blessed in his doing.
speaker: Narrator

text: If anyone thinks he is religious and does not bridle his tongue but deceives his heart, this person's religion is worthless.
speaker: Narrator

text: Religion that is pure and undefiled before God, the Father, is this: to visit orphans and widows in their affliction, and to keep oneself unstained from the world.
speaker: Narrator

text: My brothers, show no partiality as you hold the faith in our Lord Jesus Christ, the Lord of glory.
speaker: Narrator

text: For if a man wearing a gold ring and fine clothing comes into your assembly, and a poor man in shabby clothing also comes in,
speaker: Narrator

text: and if you pay attention to the one who wears the fine clothing and say, “You sit here in a good place”, while you say to the poor man, “You stand over there”, or, “Sit down at my feet”,
speaker: Narrator

text: have you not then made distinctions among yourselves and become judges with evil thoughts?
speaker: Narrator

text: Listen, my beloved brothers, has not God chosen those who are poor in the world to be rich in faith and heirs of the kingdom, which he has promised to those who love him?
speaker: Narrator

text: But you have dishonoured the poor man. Are not the rich the ones who oppress you, and the ones who drag you into court?
speaker: Narrator

text: Are they not the ones who blaspheme the honourable name by which you were called?
speaker: Narrator

text: If you really fulfil the royal law according to the Scripture, “You shall love your neighbour as yourself”, you are doing well.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if you show partiality, you are committing sin and are convicted by the law as transgressors.
speaker: Narrator

text: For whoever keeps the whole law but fails in one point has become accountable for all of it.
speaker: Narrator

text: For he who said, “Do not commit adultery”, also said, “Do not murder.” If you do not commit adultery but do murder, you have become a transgressor of the law.
speaker: Narrator

text: So speak and so act as those who are to be judged under the law of liberty.
speaker: Narrator

text: For judgement is without mercy to one who has shown no mercy. Mercy triumphs over judgement.
speaker: Narrator

text: What good is it, my brothers, if someone says he has faith but does not have works? Can that faith save him?
speaker: Narrator

text: If a brother or sister is poorly clothed and lacking in daily food,
speaker: Narrator

text: and one of you says to them, “Go in peace, be warmed and filled”, without giving them the things needed for the body, what good is that?
speaker: Narrator

text: So also faith by itself, if it does not have works, is dead.
speaker: Narrator

text: But someone will say, “You have faith and I have works.” Show me your faith apart from your works, and I will show you my faith by my works.
speaker: Narrator

text: You believe that God is one; you do well. Even the demons believe—and shudder!
speaker: Narrator

text: Do you want to be shown, you foolish person, that faith apart from works is useless?
speaker: Narrator

text: Was not Abraham our father justified by works when he offered up his son Isaac on the altar?
speaker: Narrator

text: You see that faith was active along with his works, and faith was completed by his works;
speaker: Narrator

text: and the Scripture was fulfilled that says, “Abraham believed God, and it was counted to him as righteousness”—and he was called a friend of God.
speaker: Narrator

text: You see that a person is justified by works and not by faith alone.
speaker: Narrator

text: And in the same way was not also Rahab the prostitute justified by works when she received the messengers and sent them out by another way?
speaker: Narrator

text: For as the body apart from the spirit is dead, so also faith apart from works is dead.
speaker: Narrator

text: Not many of you should become teachers, my brothers, for you know that we who teach will be judged with greater strictness.
speaker: Narrator

text: For we all stumble in many ways. And if anyone does not stumble in what he says, he is a perfect man, able also to bridle his whole body.
speaker: Narrator

text: If we put bits into the mouths of horses so that they obey us, we guide their whole bodies as well.
speaker: Narrator

text: Look at the ships also: though they are so large and are driven by strong winds, they are guided by a very small rudder wherever the will of the pilot directs.
speaker: Narrator

text:
So also the tongue is a small member, yet it boasts of great things.
How great a forest is set ablaze by such a small fire!
speaker: Narrator

text: And the tongue is a fire, a world of unrighteousness. The tongue is set among our members, staining the whole body, setting on fire the entire course of life, and set on fire by hell.
speaker: Narrator

text: For every kind of beast and bird, of reptile and sea creature, can be tamed and has been tamed by mankind,
speaker: Narrator

text: but no human being can tame the tongue. It is a restless evil, full of deadly poison.
speaker: Narrator

text: With it we bless our Lord and Father, and with it we curse people who are made in the likeness of God.
speaker: Narrator

text: From the same mouth come blessing and cursing. My brothers, these things ought not to be so.
speaker: Narrator

text: Does a spring pour forth from the same opening both fresh and salt water?
speaker: Narrator

text: Can a fig tree, my brothers, bear olives, or a grapevine produce figs? Neither can a salt pond yield fresh water.
speaker: Narrator

text: Who is wise and understanding among you? By his good conduct let him show his works in the meekness of wisdom.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if you have bitter jealousy and selfish ambition in your hearts, do not boast and be false to the truth.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is not the wisdom that comes down from above, but is earthly, unspiritual, demonic.
speaker: Narrator

text: For where jealousy and selfish ambition exist, there will be disorder and every vile practice.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the wisdom from above is first pure, then peaceable, gentle, open to reason, full of mercy and good fruits, impartial and sincere.
speaker: Narrator

text: And a harvest of righteousness is sown in peace by those who make peace.
speaker: Narrator

text: What causes quarrels and what causes fights among you? Is it not this, that your passions are at war within you?
speaker: Narrator

text: You desire and do not have, so you murder. You covet and cannot obtain, so you fight and quarrel. You do not have, because you do not ask.
speaker: Narrator

text: You ask and do not receive, because you ask wrongly, to spend it on your passions.
speaker: Narrator

text: You adulterous people! Do you not know that friendship with the world is enmity with God? Therefore whoever wishes to be a friend of the world makes himself an enemy of God.
speaker: Narrator

text: Or do you suppose it is to no purpose that the Scripture says, “He yearns jealously over the spirit that he has made to dwell in us”?
speaker: Narrator

text: But he gives more grace. Therefore it says, “God opposes the proud, but gives grace to the humble.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Submit yourselves therefore to God. Resist the devil, and he will flee from you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Draw near to God, and he will draw near to you. Cleanse your hands, you sinners, and purify your hearts, you double-minded.
speaker: Narrator

text: Be wretched and mourn and weep. Let your laughter be turned to mourning and your joy to gloom.
speaker: Narrator

text: Humble yourselves before the Lord, and he will exalt you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not speak evil against one another, brothers. The one who speaks against a brother or judges his brother, speaks evil against the law and judges the law. But if you judge the law, you are not a doer of the law but a judge.
speaker: Narrator

text: There is only one lawgiver and judge, he who is able to save and to destroy. But who are you to judge your neighbour?
speaker: Narrator

text: Come now, you who say, “Today or tomorrow we will go into such and such a town and spend a year there and trade and make a profit”—
speaker: Narrator

text: yet you do not know what tomorrow will bring. What is your life? For you are a mist that appears for a little time and then vanishes.
speaker: Narrator

text: Instead you ought to say, “If the Lord wills, we will live and do this or that.”
speaker: Narrator

text: As it is, you boast in your arrogance. All such boasting is evil.
speaker: Narrator

text: So whoever knows the right thing to do and fails to do it, for him it is sin.
speaker: Narrator

text: Come now, you rich, weep and howl for the miseries that are coming upon you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Your riches have rotted and your garments are moth-eaten.
speaker: Narrator

text: Your gold and silver have corroded, and their corrosion will be evidence against you and will eat your flesh like fire. You have laid up treasure in the last days.
speaker: Narrator

text: Behold, the wages of the labourers who mowed your fields, which you kept back by fraud, are crying out against you, and the cries of the harvesters have reached the ears of the Lord of hosts.
speaker: Narrator

text: You have lived on the earth in luxury and in self-indulgence. You have fattened your hearts in a day of slaughter.
speaker: Narrator

text: You have condemned and murdered the righteous person. He does not resist you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Be patient, therefore, brothers, until the coming of the Lord. See how the farmer waits for the precious fruit of the earth, being patient about it, until it receives the early and the late rains.
speaker: Narrator

text: You also, be patient. Establish your hearts, for the coming of the Lord is at hand.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not grumble against one another, brothers, so that you may not be judged; behold, the Judge is standing at the door.
speaker: Narrator

text: As an example of suffering and patience, brothers, take the prophets who spoke in the name of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Behold, we consider those blessed who remained steadfast. You have heard of the steadfastness of Job, and you have seen the purpose of the Lord, how the Lord is compassionate and merciful.
speaker: Narrator

text: But above all, my brothers, do not swear, either by heaven or by earth or by any other oath, but let your “yes” be yes and your “no” be no, so that you may not fall under condemnation.
speaker: Narrator

text: Is anyone among you suffering? Let him pray. Is anyone cheerful? Let him sing praise.
speaker: Narrator

text: Is anyone among you sick? Let him call for the elders of the church, and let them pray over him, anointing him with oil in the name of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the prayer of faith will save the one who is sick, and the Lord will raise him up. And if he has committed sins, he will be forgiven.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore, confess your sins to one another and pray for one another, that you may be healed. The prayer of a righteous person has great power as it is working.
speaker: Narrator

text: Elijah was a man with a nature like ours, and he prayed fervently that it might not rain, and for three years and six months it did not rain on the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he prayed again, and heaven gave rain, and the earth bore its fruit.
speaker: Narrator

text: My brothers, if anyone among you wanders from the truth and someone brings him back,
speaker: Narrator

text: let him know that whoever brings back a sinner from his wandering will save his soul from death and will cover a multitude of sins.
speaker: Narrator
